info.game_comments:
Ben Bishop game 3.

Ask Alex #6: Memory.

(1, 1).clue: In Tennessee Williams' play, streetcars named Desire & Cemetery run on a single track in this southern city

(2, 1).clue: Go figure--sand usually flows through this shapely instrument for measuring time

(3, 1).clue: Rent a streetcar for your birthday party at the Shore Line Trolley Museum in this state's East Haven

(4, 1).clue: He honored his grandfather as he & Angelina Jolie named their boy twin Knox

(5, 1).clue: I'd like a 1970 magnum of this champagne named for a 17th c. monk, please. $892?! I'd like a soda

(6, 1).clue: If a star larger than 3 solar masses completely burns its nuclear fuel, theory says it'll collapse into this

(1, 2).clue: In "The Glass Menagerie", Jim accidentally breaks the horn off this animal, the prize of Laura's collection

(2, 2).clue: The 12th & 13th c. Notre Dame de la Belle Verriere in the Chartres Cathedral is a fine example of this

(3, 2).clue: Rio de Janeiro's streetcars were once pulled by these animals, called asnos or burros

(4, 2).clue: This English rocker rhymingly named his son Zowie (he's now Joey)

(5, 2).clue: Winning $276 million in this 29-state lottery like 8 West Virginians did in 2008 wouldn't be so bad

(6, 2).clue: This constellation represents a youth pouring water from a jar

(1, 3).clue: The Pollitt Plantation in Mississippi is the setting of this Williams work
(1, 3).correct response: Cat on a Hot Tin Roof

(2, 3).clue: Aka spun glass, this is used in insulation & boat hulls

(3, 3).clue: Beginning service in 1832, this city's first streetcar ran along Bowery Street

(4, 3).clue: Moxie Crimefighter is the daughter of this taller half of a magical duo

(5, 3).clue: I wish I had a few "A" shares of this stock, BRK-A; in September 2008 they were going for $131,000 a pop

(6, 3).clue: Sagittarius is the archer & Sagitta is, appropriately, one of these with its brightest star at the point

(1, 4).clue: 1950 Williams play in which a truck driver has the title body art on his chest

(2, 4).clue: From looking at P.P.G. Place in Pittsburgh, you won't be surprised that the "P.G." stands for this material

(3, 4).clue: The first complete electric streetcar system was installed in this former Confederate capital in 1888

(4, 4).clue: Lark Song Previn is one of this actress' 14 children

(5, 4).clue: I want my kids to get scholarships to this California school near Palo Alto, as undergrad tuition is $36,030 a year

(6, 4).clue: Although Castor in Gemini is designated Alpha Geminorum, this star, Beta Geminorum, is actually brighter

(1, 5).clue: A defrocked priest is one of the characters at a seedy Mexican hotel in this 1961 play

(2, 5).clue: One of his best-known compositions is the score for the 1982 film "Koyaanisqatsi"

(3, 5).clue: This passionate Pasternak protagonist suffers a heart attack on a streetcar & dies

(4, 5).clue: Rachel Griffiths' son Banjo is named for the man who wrote this song of her native Australia

(5, 5).clue: Gimme gimme gimme one of these items from China; an underglaze copper-red one sold for $10 million in 2006

(6, 5).clue: The veil one of these in Cygnus is the remnant of a star that may have exploded 50,000 years ago

(1, 1).clue: In the first Punic War, Rome conquered this island to the south, making it the first Roman province

(2, 1).clue: In 2004 Ryoko Tani's inside leg technique brought her a second straight gold in this martial art

(3, 1).clue: The median nerve in your arm controls your pollex, better known as this digit

(4, 1).clue: Marzipan, used to cover or decorate cakes, is a paste made from this nut

(5, 1).clue: After the death of Peter the Great, this former consort took up the job of empress & wasn't great

(1, 2).clue: A quarter of a million people crowded into this largest hippodrome to watch the chariot races

(2, 2).clue: This decathlete from Mount Kisco, N.Y. lit up Montreal's Olympic Stadium at the 1976 games

(3, 2).clue: The vagus nerve, from the Latin for "wandering", is the longest of these 12 sets of nerves arising in the brainstem

(4, 2).clue: To make edible flowers & ribbons, sugar can be pulled, spun or this, as in making glass

(5, 2).clue: Fined $100 for voting in an 1873 Rochester election, she said, "I shall never pay a dollar of your unjust penalty"

(6, 2).clue: The power to affect persons or events

(1, 3).clue: The Curia was the meeting place of this most powerful political body in the Republic

(2, 3).clue: This Pittsburgh Penguins great was the captain of Canada's 2002 gold-medal hockey team

(3, 3).clue: When you're talking about the C8 spinal nerves, the C stands for this

(4, 3).clue: Good modeling chocolate has a high content of this fatty solid that comes from the seeds of the bean

(5, 3).clue: This witty woman who helped found the Screen Writers Guild left her estate to Martin Luther King Jr.

(6, 3).clue: A series of decorative grooves on an architectural column

(1, 4).clue: He was the first Roman emperor, & his 40-year reign marked the beginning of the Pax Romana

(2, 4).clue: In both '84 & '88, Greg Louganis doubled up in diving, winning gold in platform & this

(3, 4).clue: (Kelly of the Clue Crew shows a diagram on the monitor.)  Neurons receive impulses with these structures that branch out, giving them this name from the Greek for tree

(4, 4).clue: This decorative flourish on a cake shares its name with the ornamental band on upholstery

(5, 4).clue: After hearing a song by this poetess, the Athenian ruler Solon wanted to "learn it and die"

(1, 5).clue: In 330 A.D. the capital of the Roman Empire moved from Rome to this city much farther east

(2, 5).clue: On a sweltering July 10, 1924 this Finn set Olympic records in the 1,500 & 5,000 meters

(3, 5).clue: This cluster of nerves behind the stomach controls vital functions; a punch that penetrates there slows you down

(4, 5).clue: French for "melting", this pliable sugar mixture is rolled & used as an icing to cover cakes of any shape & size

(5, 5).clue: Female name given to the fossil found by Donald Johanson in Hadar, Ethiopia in 1974

(6, 5).clue: Adjective meaning serving no purpose, or more than is required

(0, 0).clue: Some people in this Asian country named for a European king now want to call it by an indigenous name, Maharlika
